title: 109_s3514
content: The Act may be cited as the "Social Security Number Online Protection Act of 2006". The inappropriate display of social security account numbers has led to various illegal activities, including fraud and identity theft. The Federal Government's requirement for individuals to obtain and maintain a social security number has unintentionally made it a tool for crime and privacy invasions. The Federal Government aims to prevent the misuse of social security numbers by taking steps to limit their exposure in public documents, which are increasingly being stored and accessed online. This is crucial due to the risk of identity theft and fraud associated with the widespread display of these numbers. The new chapter prohibits state and local governments from displaying the last 4 digits of social security account numbers on the internet. The new chapter prohibits state and local governments from displaying the last 4 digits of social security account numbers on the internet. Violators may face civil penalties of up to $5,000 per day for substantial noncompliance. The Attorney General can take legal action against entities or individuals who display the last 4 digits of social security numbers online, with penalties of up to $5,000 per day for noncompliance. The text discusses the requirement for encryption or security measures when transmitting social security numbers online. Failure to do so may result in penalties. The security account number is assigned by the Commissioner of Social Security and includes derivatives of the number. A clerical amendment is made to the table of parts in the United States Code. The amendment prohibits state and local governments from displaying social security account numbers on the internet. Grants are provided to help them comply with the prohibition on displaying the last 4 digits of social security account numbers. Effective immediately for violations occurring after the enactment of the Act. The Attorney General awards grants to States and political subdivisions to remove or redact the last 4 digits of social security numbers from public records displayed online. States must apply for grants, and $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2007 and 2008. The Attorney General awards grants to States and territories to remove or redact social security numbers from public records online, including 50 States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the United States Virgin Islands, Guam, and the Northern Marianas.
